dialogues.text: Mr. Gorman, the city of Metropolis is generous to a fault, but. . .

dialogues.text: Thirty-six weeks of chronic unemployment, thirty-six weeks of living off the taxes of hard-working citizens. Do you know what you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me a bum! I ain't no bum!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are, I was about to say, no longer eligible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . Bermuda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARK'S eyes widen at the image that comes to his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Mr. White, the next number, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'm I supposed to turn this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrating, she tumbles   the drum over by hand) By hand. Like the pioneers did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't we just get a computer to  do this?

dialogues.speaker: WEBCO INDUSTRIES
dialogues.text: The room we ENTER is one of those enormous computer cente the massive data consoles, their tape decks alternately r Other machines extrude massive print-outs. In the center one after another, with small table-top computer consoles operated from a keyboard. VARIOUS WORKERS are seen doing the ones operating the keyboard computers. They move rapi and unique fashion: each WORKER sits on a chair that has they propel themselves from terminal to terminal by skitt leaving their chairs. To facilitate this action, they all shoes, which grips the floor for maximum purchase. The im of robot-like humans zipping around from machine to machi WIDE SHOT, REVERSE --  Revealing that the rolling cart wh room is pushed by an EMPLOYEE who stops at each desk and envelope . . . it's payday and they're getting their payc we SEE in F.G. two desks, side by side, with a keyboard c display on each.  One of them is manned by our friend wit GORMAN. Across the aisle is his fellow-worker, FRED. The MAN handing out the checks stops at GUS' desk, gives GUS takes the envelope, opens it, as FRED gets the same a on. CLOSE ON GUS -- He looks in astonished dismay at his chec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonofagun! Look at this here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First paycheck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First rip-off, man! Supposed to be 225 bucks a week! You know what this sucker

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: says?? $143.80! (reading it, angry) Federal tax! State tax! Social Security tax!

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: That's so you're still getting some money when you hit 65.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (gets up, starts to walk) I ain't gonna live that long on $143.80! I want it now, man, while I'm still young and cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS and FRED enter the cafeteria, continuing their conver THEM, as they walk down to the coffee machine. GUS mutter with no success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's probably more like $143.80 and one-half cent. (GUS gives him a  puzzled look) There's always fractions over in a big corporation, but they round it down to the lowest whole number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'm I gonna do with half a cent? Buy me a thoroughbred cockroach? (pause; he starts to  Everybody loses them fractions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't actually lose 'em. You can't lose  what you never got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gets it, the company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not really. They can't be bothered collecting half a cent from your paycheck  anymore than you could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where is all them half-centses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just . . . floating around out there. The computer knows where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. GUS -- lost in thought NEW ANGLE -- By now they've reached the coffee urn. FRED fills two cups, reaches for the bowl of sugar cubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many sugars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One. (pause. As FRED drops one in the cup) And a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT -- The end of the day. Employees putting on the the white sneakers into normal street shoes, leaving, say ON GUS -- Seated at his keyboard, a faintly manic gleam i at the video display screen, his fingers brushing the key NEW ANGLE -- FRED puts on his jacket, gets ready to leave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quittin' time, Gus. Comin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh . . . no, man. I got some work to finish up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (archly) Workin' overtime? What are you doin', buddy, looking for a raise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) Yeah. A raise . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED shakes his head, turns, and leaves. LONG SHOT -- the data processing center is empty of PEOPL computers and GUS. MED. CLOS ON GUS -- he takes his paycheck out of the enve closely at it. INSERT -- ON THE UPPER RIGHT CORNER OF THE CHECK is a sho and letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating them aloud) 368zzx4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ANGLE -- he punches those numbers and letters on hi ON THE VIDEO DISPLAY -- the numbers and letters appear on moment later: HELLO. WEBCO PAYROLL DIVISION. GIVE COMMAND COORDINATES. ON GUS -- a broad grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a man who sees the future opening before him) Yeah !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to punch coordinates into the keyboard. In a QUICK SERIES OF SHOTS, WE SEE VARIOUS COMPUTERS OF D DIFFERENT LOCATION as they begin to flash, and/or light u memory bank tapes and/or beep and/or do other 'computer s clearly indicate that what GUS is doing is having a resul activating other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT -- A Greyhound bus is travelling down a tw runs alongside a woodsy, rural area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of the PASSENGERS are sleeping. A few read by the l overhead lights. Perhaps a couple cuddling in the back se toward the rear of the bus are CLARK and JIMMY. CLARK is to seem interested in what is obviously an interminable s telling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my Uncle Al, on my father's side, he won't eat her stuffing, he says it should be cooked on the outside of the turkey and she puts the stuffing inside the turkey. So my mother told my Aunt Ellen . . . Aunt Ellen's my father's half-sister, I told you that, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmm . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is though, my cousin Arnold, Aunt Rosey's Arnold this is, he got mad when Uncle Al insulted his mother's  stuffing, so now the problem is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly alert, looking forward) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV: LOOKING FORWARD DOWN THE AILSE -- The bus has stoppe we SEE a red glow on the horizon that lights up the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, what a beautiful sunrise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one o'clock in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSER ON THE WINDSHIELD -- We now SEE police cars with d road, barrier set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later. The BUS DRIVER has gotten out to tal blocking the road. CLARK, JIMMY, and some OTHER PASSENGER bus also to find out what's happening. Throughout the following, CUT TO VARIOUS ANGLES showing o halted and one lane cleared for emergency vehicles to pass throu trucks, National Guard truck, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your choice. Turn back or pull over to the side of the road till it's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long'll that take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know with forest fires. And this one is spreading like . . . (he has no choice but to finish the sentence he started) . . . wildfire. We got 10,000 acres of timber going up like matchsticks and a south wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the south wind got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iroquois Trail Power Plant is just eight miles south of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nuclear power station?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY turns and runs back onto the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY grabs his camera from the overhead rack, dashes out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine times out of ten it's some careless camper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there campers trapped in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing our best to get 'em out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY comes out of the bus, pulls CLARK aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep talking to that state trooper so he doesn't notice where I'm going, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what Mr. White said. A  photographer always goes after a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to sneak off into the nearby forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy, it's dangerous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On JIMMY -- The swashbuckling bravado of a 19 year-old:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danger? That goes with the territory,  Mr. Kent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he ducks into the woods. C.U. CLARK -- making a decision. NEW ANGLE -- As more cars have been stooped, a DRIVER, in car to walk forward toward the barrier to see what's goin around to make sure nobody is noticing him. Then, quickly hand side back door of the empty car and enters. A split- from the left-hand side as . . . SUPERMAN! He takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVERHEAD SHOTS (STOCK FOOTAGE): A terrific forest fire is miles of burning trees, rushing winds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. Flaming trees, timber crashing. 2. Animals running in panic. 3. Sheets of flame sweeping through woods. Followed by VARIOUS QUICK SHOTS of brave and hard-working the thick of it, doing what they can: 1. Spading up the ground with shovels and hoes, trying to create firebreaks. 2. Chain-saws at work bringing down trees to to clear area. 3. A portable pump with hose attached drawing water from a small pond or creek in the area. Throughout all this, we have the impression of a blazing proportions with sheets of flame and sounds of fire and f whipping winds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT -- The command post of the firefighting with MEDICS ready; fire trucks; hot soup and coffee wagon FIREFIGHTERS getting a break, taking oxygen, drinking cof putting on their gear. CLOSER-- THE FIRE CHIEF, clad in woodsy rainment, but wit status, stands conferring with his AIDE. He looks haggard holds a walkie-talkie. Suddenly, SUPERMAN lands in the ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, how can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to assistant) Get this man a helmet and a --- (suddenly realizes  Oh! It's you! (calling to assistant) No helmet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the story?

dialogues.speaker: FIRE CHIEF
dialogues.text: This is a fierce one, Superman. We've

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: got a hundred and twenty men on the  northeast border building firebreaks. I've  got volunteers coming in from as far  away as Ohio. They're doing all they can, but -- CAMERA PANS TO SEE EXHAUSTED FIREFIGHTERS, faces covered the ground and breathing deeply from oxygen masks, trying together, as speech continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRE CHIEF (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: they're only human. PAN CONINUES TO A NEARBY AREA WHERE WE SEE, coming toward bedraggled and besmirched BOY SCOUT TROOP 9about EIGHT BO who were obviously evacuated from the forest. They are al dirty looks to someone who walks a few paces behind them: looking very forlorn and guilty, holding two fire making is obviously the twerp who started the forest fire in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of the forest, a log cabin sits in a cleari those butane gas tanks. The fire envelops it. NEW ANGLE -- The butane tank explodes. The cabin explodes seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaping out from the tops of the trees, whizzing on the h fire balls sail through the air. ON AN UNSCHORCHED PART OF THE FOREST -- Fire balls land i VARIOUS ANGLES, WE SEE new fires start up. NEW ANGLE -- as FIREFIGHTERS race into this area and begi fresh brushfires with shovels and picks, trying to exting before they really get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- A wooden tower used for fire-spotting in the From this distance, we can barely make out that somebody tower, standing on the ledge. CLOSER ON THE TOWER -- It's JIMMY OLSEN, who has secured vantage point for taking photos of the fire. WIDE ANGLE ON THE TOWER--what he doesn't realize is that up behind the tower and will soon envelop it.

dialogues.text: VARIOUS SHOTS OF FIREFIGHTERS building firebreaks. It is process. Some MEN chop down trees to clear the break line earth with spades. Others haul the fallen timber out of t feverishly, but it's hard work and slow going. NEW ANGLE  -- SUPERMAN lands in their midst. They're so e barely muster up the customary surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all business) Stand back, guys. Where do you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: want this firebreak?

dialogues.speaker: CREW LEADER
dialogues.text: (pointing) From there to there. FAVORING SUPERMAN as he quickly selects a stout, tall tre astonishment, SUPERMAN grabs the base of the tree and wit EFFECTS: SUPER-STRENGTH (and a bit of super-strain) he pu ground, roots and all. Quickly he hauls it to a clear area and ties a length of creating an instant harness for himself. NEW ANGLE -- He throws the cable over his shoulders, hook begins to race at: EFFECTS: SUPER-SPEED straight through the heavily wooded behind him like a horizontal plow, knocks down all the tr fall to either side like so many pick-up sticks. LONG SHOT -- The FIREFIGHTERS stand at the point of his d instant firebreak being created before their eyes. LONG WIDE ANGLE DOWN (ARIAL SHOT) -- We SEE the firebreak trees crashing down to the ground on either side of the b SUPERMAN. ON THE FORMAN OF THE FIREBREAK CREW, who speaks into his central command post:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, this is the North Boundary Crew. We've got a firebreak that should contain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it on our end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to walkie-talkie) It's not going to be that easy on the south side. The winds are blowing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fireballs right over the breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT -- An icon of our times: the three conc with nuclear energy stations, c.f. Three Mile Island. In the glow of the fire. ON THE GATE surrounding the tower closest to the forest. SECURITY MEN, etc. are standing there watching the approa binoculars. Behind them, we SEE the largest of the towers A very worried PLANT SUPERVISOR puts downs his binoculars SECURITY CHIEF standing beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, if that fire gets much closer, we're going to have ourselves some big trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nuclear reactor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) You figure it out. That -- (points at tower)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is a cooling tower, right? The  nuclear core inside it is stabilized by the temperature. If the fire gets here, it'll stop being a cooling tower, and turn into a furnace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! You mean a melt-down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the civil defense people on the phone. We may have to evacuate the whole damn state!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An A-frame summer cottage has been constructed in a clear FAVORS the big glass faзade of it, one enormous picture w The window reflects the fire coming closer to the house. CLOSER ON THE GLASS as is begins to heat up and distort t encroaching flames. Suddenly, the window buckles and blow crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT -- HEADING TOWARD CAMERA, a camper trailer is speeding down a dirt road, trying to get to safety. Bu already caught on fire.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CAB
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- Finally, as the flames begin to consume more DRIVER brakes to a halt. HE and his family run like hell trailer explodes in a ball of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHIEF looks incredulous at something he's just heard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What                         (to walkie-talkie) How did he get there? (to AIDE beside him) Some lunatic is up in the watch- tower taking pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that tower's right in the  middle of pure hell right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE ON THE TOP OF THE TOWER -- JIMMY is taking pho excited that he doesn't realize what danger he's in. LONG SHOT -- The flames attack the struts of the tower. T The entire tower buckles and topples forward like a man w broken legs. TIGHTER ANGLE -- As it falls. JIMMY is hurled out of the ON JIMMY-- He lays there, moaning in pain, clutching his Surrounded by fire. Things look very bad for him. ANGLE UP -- Suddenly, SUPERMAN appears walking through a unhurt by the fire. He makes his way to the fallen JIMY, out of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The area of the command post where the ambulances are wai MEDICS, etc. stand by. SUPERMAN lands with JIMMY in his arms and gently lays him stretchers just by the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in pain) It's my leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERMAN looks at Jimmy's leg. We see an X-ray shot of th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the MEDIC) It's a clean break right across the fibula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO COMMAND POST as a breathless FIREFIGHTER runs up t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water supply is practically gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) We've got to get water!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? Lake Comooga is five miles from here. We haven't got a five mile hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. SUPERMAN -- as he hears about the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is this lake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points) That way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERMAN immediately flies off in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. WIDE SHOT -- SUPERMAN lands at the edge of a lake ab wide. He surveys the expanse of water before him. Then: SPECIAL EFFECTS: He blows a steady gust of ice-breath acr lake. In moments, the entire surface freezes solid. NEW ANGLE -- He bends down and grasps the edge of the ice It's about five-inches thick. Slowly, he begins to pull a time. WIDE SHOT -- The entire platter of ice, the size of the l top. Holding it before him, SUPERMAN flies into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An amazing sight: SUPERMAN FLYING toward the glowing red fire rages, holding the enormous ice platter before him. He arrives over the center of the forest fire. He flings the fire. As the ice starts to fall, the heat from below into a tremendous torrent of water. VARIOUS ANGLES -- The melted lake water puts out  the maj ON THE GROUND, REACTIONS from the FIREFIGHTERS, etc. Tota

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flames have spread to the base of the tower now, lick of WORKERS, SCIENTISTS et al have been hastily organized units. They are hosing down the sides of the main tower, Steam erupts as the water hits the hot concrete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not going to work! It's too hot  now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERMAN flies at top speed toward the Iroquois Trail tow INTERCUT SHOTS of SUPERMAN closer to the familiar silos a ground, trying to hose down the silo and put out the encr around it. LONG SHOT -- SUPERMAN flies directly into the largest con

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound: a strident alarm going continuously, a sound of pa ON A GAUGE -- A needle has zipped into the Red for Danger wildly at the end of the scale. PULL BACK TO REVEAL a harried SCIENTIST in white coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going right off the end of the scale, Dr. Harris!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT -- The outer chamber of the reactor. SCIENTISTS manning dials. Behind three thick glass shields we SEE in where no man can go. Mechanical robot-arms are controlled chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start the emergency cooling procedure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSER ON THE WINDOW showing the inner chamber -- all sta tile. In the center, on a kind of platform, the nuclear c emanating pulsations of radiation. A fearful thing. It ap cylinders, each about a foot long, and as it approaches d cylinders (one above the other) are moving closer and clo is clear that if they join it will be irrevocable. Melt-d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't helping! We're about two minutes from melt-down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, SUPERMAN lands inside the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superman! (talking though intercom) Be careful! There's enough radiation in that core to light up the whole  country for a year!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll just stabilize it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSER -- SUPERMAN grasps the red-hot cylinders. A fleeti face lets us know the even he finds this pretty hot stuff caution and great power, he pulls the two cylinders apart back into their housing. ON THE GAGE -- The needle drops back to NORMAL. Sound: the alarm that has been ringing suddenly quits. REACTIONS -- Incredible relief from the SCIENTISTS. Moppi SUPERMAN smile to the scientists and flies up and out of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in wonderment) It isn't very scientific, gentlemen, but I tell you that man is a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. (PROFILE) of a very little OLD LADY: ancient, now-re BANISTER, peering at the shirt and tie on a chest, which level. As she cranes her neck upwards to address the head and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really have grown, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE PAN UP WITH HER GAZE to REVEAL CLARK KENT smiling gent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking well, Miss Bannister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDER -- The gym is decorated: crepe paper, balloons, pos and blow-ups of the old black and white graduation photos including one of the series, studios, bespectacled young standard yearbook shots of the great moments of the class Senior Prom, production of 'Our Town,' etc.). Surrounded by COUPLES dancing tot he strains of Golden Ol school era, CLARK continues to make polite chat with MINN suddenly, he focuses on something across the room.  CLARK'S POV: Across the room, a YOUNG WOMAN about his age gym, carrying a stack of records in one arm and a stack o other. Red-haired and very pretty in an all-American way, the kind of girl who would instantly be surrounded by fri Oddly, she's not. In fact, she is the only woman here wit date. As if to platy down her aloneness, she instantly ge checking the refreshments and adjusting a loose decoratio picks up her plates and records again and turns to CAMERA spaces between dancing COUPLES, something that makes her C.U. LANA -- Her eyes sparkling with delight as she mimes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. CLARK -- A warm smile for her as he too mouths her n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANA?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we are SEEING all this interplay, we are at the same t MINNIE BANNISTER (o.s.) I can't complain. Oh, I take the  stairs a bit slower these days, and of course I get theses spells, but I can't complain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me, Miss Bannister? There's someone I really have to say hello to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- FULL SHOT as they make their way to each oth CLOSER -- There's a lot of unspoken past history between he had a serious crush on her during all his young years she didn't acknowledge it then. Now, fifteen years later, see each other         again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lana Lang. How great to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suddenly leans forward and kisses him on the cheek. (A NOTE ON LANA LANG: Lana is one of these people, who, b exigencies of her situation, seems to be carrying on thre and often doing two or three different tasks at once. Alt perfectly clear in their own minds about the direction th in, it's often confusing and disconcerting to others. As three conversation balls in the air simultaneously, Clark with her, getting lost in the conversation, thinking she in fact she's gone on to another subject. The effect is c unsettling for him, and should finally be genuinely charm eyes. In the dialogue as written, Lana's separate thought breaks and indications, but in performance they should ru non-stop).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always did. (indicating plates and dishes) Can I give you a hand with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking toward the buffet table. TRACK WITH TH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can mange, This is the first time you've been back since your mom passed away, isn't it? (as he nods) I can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can mange, This is the first time you've been back since your mom passed away, isn't it? (as he nods) I can't believe it. You came all the  way from Metropolis just for this dinky little reunion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't say that, you're the chairman -- (uncertainly) ...uh, chairperson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struck by the thought) And here I am, just standing  here. That's terrible. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) You're welcome...??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For reminding me, I mean. Can you follow me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She changes direction, starts to walk toward the music ar record player set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows her. As they reach the TEENAGE D.J.:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to give these to the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling at CLARK, she doesn't realize she setting the pap down by the D.J.'s set-up. The D.J. is about to protest, turned away and walks briskly to the nearby buffet table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you and Donald split up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANA seems not to hear him as she sets the stack of recor table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you eat yet?

dialogues.text: Well, I always wished you  would. Back when you were -- (he hesitates)

dialogues.text: ON LANA -- as she reaches up and takes down a big, captio LANA and a YOUNG MAN (DONALD) dressed as King and Queen o DONALD is grinning proudly at the camera while LANA gazes

dialogues.text: (but she meant something else, as she points to  buffet table:) There must be a gallon of potato salad left over.

dialogues.text: You know what's the problem?

dialogues.text: Mayonnaise? Donald loved mayonnaise. Why would you

dialogues.text: think that was the problem.?

dialogues.text: (very confused) I didn't --

dialogues.speaker: LANA

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: But Lana, you could --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully) That's easy to say. But how? And what about Ricky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely at sea) Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ricky. My little boy. At least here we've got a house. and I've got a job. Okay, I'm only a  secretary, oaky, but it pays the bills. Except for last winter when the fuel bills kept going up and up and up. (extendes her hand, eyes her bare ring finger) I even had to pawn my diamond

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ring then. ON CLARK -- Distressed for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: QUICK C. U. CLARK -- A fleeting, private smile. NEW ANGLE -- As CLARK starts to gather up the fallen stre LANA glances over at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively) You...um...you never got married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing quietly,          his favorite oldie) "Earth Angel, Earth Angel, Please be mine...

dialogues.text: ON LANA -- She stops and turns, looks at him fondly, smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That song. I remember one day I came into the music room and you were fooling around at the  piano. And I thought -- what am I going to do with all this potato salad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) You thought that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going back to  square one) I thought "Clark Kent has a  really nice voice." You didn't even know I was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON CLARK -- He stops singing, almost blushing. ON LANA -- She hasn't noticed. She is standing looking at yet been taken down from the wall -- that smiling and ser CLARK KENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You know, years later you can look at someone and think, well, I guess that's the one, that's the one that got away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. CLARK -- That really got to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ROSS WEBSTER in a spectacularly lush office, filled wi dйcor. This is our first meeting with the man himself and style is that calculatedly gruff "democratic" jolly camar Nelson Rockefeller. in other words, this is a guy who ins servants call him by his first name, but that doesn't mea one to sit at his table. At this moment in time, the Huma clearly upset about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me again, fella. Just run it by me one more time.

dialogues.text: REVERSE, WIDE ANGLE -- Standing on the other side of the elderly man in a dark business suit who looks extremely i Chief Accountant of Webco. MR. SIMPSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extremely nervous) 85,000 dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missing????

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embezzled, Mr. Webster. (he can barely say it) Stolen from the firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From off-screen, a strident voice that could curdle milk voice of VERA WEBSTER, the sister. VERA (o.s.) By whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOTH MEN turn sharply in the direction of the voice. PAN to an anteroom. Dressed in a suit that somehow reminds us VERA, in a foul mood, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I want to know! By whom? Whom????

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a hold of yourself, Vera. (under his breath) Nobody else ever will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who. Whom. I can't trace it. (years of bitterness coming out) In the old days it was simple. We  kept books, we had ledgers, we could see what was going in and what was paid out. If somebody wanted to rob you, he'd come in with a gun and say 'stick 'em up." (frustrated) Now they get theses blasted computers to do their dirty work!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend, you are yesterday. Whoever pulled this caper is  tomorrow.

dialogues.text: Suddenly, the door flies open and LORELEI bursts in, all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: (ill-at-ease) Now, Vera...uh, Simpson, you  know my Staff Dietician?

dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.text: (to LORELEI) If you don't mind, we are trying to hold a meeting here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you hold your breath, instead? Maybe you'll turn blue. On you that'd be an improvement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay attention, people: I am about to take a human life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS quickly intervenes, upset at this turn of events. he apart and:

dialogues.text: SIMPSON departs; the TWO WOMEN explode in anger, simultan

dialogues.text: Bubba, I will not let                            Ross, te this woman insult me...                            pickin

dialogues.text: (commandingly, in  stentorian tones) Mouths ...closed! Ears...open! (cowed, scared, the  WOMEN shut up) Now the last thing any of us  wants is for me to be upset. Right?

(reluctant murmurs of                 assent from the WOMEN)         Now...kiss and make up. Surely, LORELEI pursers her lips.

dialogues.text: Well, chum? What now? Kiss the 85 thou goodbye? Pay some thief's salary while he thinks up new ways to shake the money tree?

dialogues.text: (helpfully) He's bound to slip up sooner or later.

dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...I don't know...that's what  they always say in the movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS paces, building up steam. A slow burn heating up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless the man's a complete idiot, he won't slip up at all. He'll just go

dialogues.text: on quietly taking the bread from  our mouths. unless he's a total  ignoramus, he'll keep a low profile and won't do a thing to call attention  to himself. (voice rising) Unless he is an utter moron... Suddenly: Sound: A loud sports car motor revs up outside the window last lap at Sebring. FULL SHOT -- ROSS, VERA, LORELEI, and SIMPSON, startled a to the window to look out and see what it is. POV: OUT THE WINDOW -- The company parking lot. Zooming d then executing a hairpin turn, burning rubber and pulling is an incredible bright red Ferrari...the flashiest of sp imagine;. Behind the wheel still dressed in his shabby, s GORMAN.

dialogues.text: (distressed) I just can't stand this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be positive) Hey, he'll be all right. Believe me Lana, I know. I was a late bloomer myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't only that he's small for his age. how would you like to be the only kid in town without a father? (as she looks in another direction) Look at him, he's stewed to the gills in the middle of the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking at

dialogues.text: I mean him. She points, and CAMERA FOLLOWS HER GESTURE TO REVEAL BRAD toward them from the bar, a bottle of beer in his hand.

dialogues.text: Uh, no, I didn't know that, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A natural athlete can play any sport. Any sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. This'll only make it worse.

dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- RICKY, first to bowl, lifts a ball from the really too heavy for him to handle well, but he gamely ta line and, a bit clumsily, bowls a wobbly ball.         ON THE BALL -- it pretty much runs out of steam by the ti but manages to knock down a few. ON RICKY -- looking disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? What'd I tell ya?

dialogues.text: As RICKY goes to get the ball coming back on the rack for lurches over to him, putting on a big helpful show for LA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) Say, Brad. I think he'll be  better off doing it his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed at the effrontery) For a guy who was lucky to be  water-boy on the high school team, you sure got a big mouth, Kent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARK moves closer to him to speak in confidence: MOVE IN SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voice) I just think Ricky would rather not get a bowling lesson in front of the other kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid needs a man to show him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid will do fine on his own. (to RICKY) Give it your best shot, Ricky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As RICKY walks to his position behind the line: ON CLARK -- who seemingly "accidentally" trips over the c knocking it over. The hunk of chalk breaks and chalk dust CLARK tries to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (derisively) Clark Klutz. Same as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON RICKY -- holding the heavy ball, he advances to the li C.U. LANA -- eyes averted. C.U. CLARK -- chalk dust on his face, his nose starts to to sneeze. ON RICKY -- he bowls the ball, rather weekly. C.U. CLARK -- who points his face at the line and lets ou EFFECTS: The Super-Sneeze causes the ball to whiz down th It hits the pins with such impact that they break into a many china cups. C.U. RICKY -- astonished. And then joyfully delighted. C.U. BRAD -- his jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to CLARK) Gezundheit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS seated at his computer, at work. His neighbor FRED co aisle, looking serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boss wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feet churning rapidly, GUS propels his rolling chair towa

dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- the glass elevator begins its ascent tot he management, the office of  ROSS WEBSTER himself. Inside, shakes and quakes in full view of everybody in the lobby

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abject terror) Oh my God! The Boss! Ross the Boss! The Ross!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At which point the elevator reaches another level. Seeing him, GUS manages a sickly smile, which vanishes the insta MAN'S sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS steps out of the elevator, nervously working his yo-y now that he's come into some money; this is a plastic one trembling before the desk of a snooty SECRETARY. A gold p reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gorman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking fast, in pure fear) No! He died last week. I  just look something like him. People always make this mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Webster is waiting to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He alone? Or is there, like uh... men in uniform...or, uh...plain clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please go in, Mr. Gorman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating his idea of a white executive- type) Say, dear, where's the wash room located? I'd like to  freshen up a bit before...

dialogues.text: ROSS'S voice barks out over the intercom on her desk: ROSS (o.s.) (intercom) Is he here yet, Miss Collins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing intercom  button) Yes sir, I'm sending him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingering hi yo-yo like it was a rosary, GUS enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT -- a wall of bookcases, massively out-sized che gadgets. Seated behind a massive desk, ROSS looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. August Gorman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON GUS -- instantly abject, pleading pitifully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mr. Webster, you're a great humanitarian. Ain't you heard what it's like in them jails? You send an innocent                         boy in and he gets thrown in with killers and robbers and         rapers and raper killer and robber rapers and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gorman, just answer me one question...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS braces himself for the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been a naughty boy haven't you? (congenial laugh) C'mon now, admit it, you were kinda naughty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a but surprises at his tone) Uh...yeah. I didn't think of it that way exactly, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS rises, walks up to the bookshelf and pushes the spin Suddenly the entire section of shelving revolves, reveali on the other side. As he does this business, he keeps spe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, fella, I understand. I  can -- what do the kids say these days -- "dig where you're comin' from." (a chuckle) You want to be rich, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now me, I was born rich. I've  never worn the same pair of socks twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Yeah? What do you do with 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS has by now poured himself a drink and one for GUS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe they're laundered and sent to some charitable institution. I don't know what the heck they do with 'em.  Maybe they use them for dust

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rags, or pen wipers...

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Or socks.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Yes! That never occurred to me. (hands him his drink) Her ya go, buddy, single-malt.                 (GUS downs it chug- a-lug) Gus, my friend, you're a genius. Okay, a naughty genius, but hell, nobody's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: 'Cause I know about getting' them half-centses? ROSS begins to stride about the office as he pontificates GUS, speaking "to the world." As he does, GUS, feeling mo the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because computers run the world today, pal. And the fella who can fool the computers will run the world himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS leans against the bar. It instantly revolves, taking becomes a wall of bookcase again. GUS is now trapped behi the wall. ROSS, who hasn't noticed since his back is to t talking as if GUS were still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been searching for a long time for somebody who can make these machines do things they're not supposed to do. Do you catch my drift, brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside the wall, GUS calls for help; his voice is so just takes it for a grunt of assent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you would. And best of all, you seem to be able to do it in such a way that the deed goes undetected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last the bookcase spins around and a shaken GUS steps as ROSS turns. He never noticed his absence. By the time GUS has regained his balance, ROSS is already room so that GUS has to rush to catch up with him. As ROS adjoining room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, Webco, the Webster industrial complex, is a family-owned cartel. A little magnesium here, a little zinc there. Some railroads here, some farm machinery there. You follow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little out of breath) I'm tryin' to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intensely) Gus, do you know what I want now? I want coffee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly turning to get it) Black or regular?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS and GUSS step into an enormous rooftop botanical gar football field, filled with a great profusion of trees, p bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wide-eyed wonder) Man, what is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plants. Plants always make an office cozier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS waves at a GARDNER pruning some bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, fella, how's it goin'? (to GUS) Helluva nice guy, been with me for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they stroll, ROSS stops to admire a shrub, or inspect right on talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under different company names. I  control the price of coffee beans in Brazil. The price in Venezuela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Java, South Korea, North Korea, the Aleutian Islands, Guam, Bolivia, and the Republic of Gabon!

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Decaffeinated too? As they continue walking, ROSS throws an avuncular, democ shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But y'see, chum, the problem I got is that one country just won't play ball with me. (as if GUS could empathize) You know how that can just bug a guy, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his expression darkens) Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Columbia's got two major exports and one of them's coffee. (Continued)      ROSS (cont.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (put-upon) Oh, I tried to reason with  them. Believe me, I tried! But this one miserable piss- ant little country has the gall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to think they can dictate the economy of an open market! ("reasonably") Gus, dear Gus, don't you see what I mean? We have to teach them a lesson. (icy) Wipe 'em out!!!

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (startled) Wipe 'em out?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Destroy the entire Colombian coffee crop down to the last bean. He stops by a shrub, looks down at the soil around it. He to the GARDNER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo! Over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GARDNER runs over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly terse, curt) What's this I see? Fallen leaves not picked up? Organic litter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir, I was going to do it late--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a word, ROSS slaps the MAN sharply across the fac grin appearing again, he puts his arm around GUS and they nothing unusual has happened (though, a nervous GUS keeps GARDNER).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, fella? You see the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively) But Mr. Webster...you're doin' okay with Brazil and them other places. What's wrong with just one little old country doin' their own thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very wise man once said...I think it was Attila the Hun... "It's not enough that I succeed. Everyone else must fail." (he snaps a rose in half; GUS jumps) And you are going to do it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared) Me? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their tour of the atrium has brought them back to where t connecting door tot he office. The voice of VERA, o.s., a there.                 VERA (o.s.) The weather!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ROSS and GUS come back into the office, GUS  catches h VERA, looking forbidding. ON GUS -- he instantly shrinks back from this creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to ROSS) Hey listen, I didn't know your mama was comin' by...

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: (furious) Sister! I'm his sister!

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (to GUS) Gus, tell me, have you ever heard of Vulcan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to VERA) That what they call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through her teeth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vulcan is the weather satellite government put up in orbit to monitor the weather.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (eagerly) But if somebody re-programmed it, it could do much more.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: It could make weather!

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Storms! Floods!

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: Blizzards! Heat waves!

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: How do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Like everything else in the 20th century, Gus. You push buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: a finger is pushing a button. It's JIMMY OLSEN ta says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT -- The subjects of JIMMY'S photo are smiling so might burst. They are MR. and MRS. MAURY STOKIS, the winn contest. Clad in resort outfits, they are standing beneat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it! It's the first time I ever won anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kittenish) You won my hand, Maury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, but this is the first time I ever won anything valuable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- revealing JIMMY, who has his leg in a cast. equipment, clearly not thrilled with his assignment. Stan HENDERSON, looking delighted, and PERRY WHITE. looking li to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get one with the sombreros,  Olsen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pops the outsized sombreros on the heads of the happy strike a Latin pose and grin steadily at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an inspiration) Mr. White, you be in this shot, handing them their plane tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserable) Why do I have to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserable) Why do I have to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! You're lucky I didn't fire you. I get a chance at exclusive on-the-spot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pictures of the biggest forest fire in history and what does he come back  with??? A broken leg and twelve melted rolls of film.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It was hot!

dialogues.speaker: MISS HENDERSON
dialogues.text: Smile, Mr. White.

dialogues.speaker: MR. STOKIS
dialogues.text: South America! I can't believe my luck! They freeze in the pose as the flashbulb goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS, ROSS, and VERA as we left them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computers talk to other computers, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow your twisted little mind should be able to figure out how to tap into the main computer at the  Aerospace Center and reach Vulcan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (immediately)                                 Through the telephone line terminal, that ain't nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)                                 Oh Bubba, think of the possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What she call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bubba. (GUS ties not to snicker) When she was three years old she couldn't pronounce the word 'brother' and it came out 'Bubba.' (grimly) It was the last cute thing she ever did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without knocking, as usual, LORELEI bursts into the offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I hear somebody say "cute thing?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS is stupefied at the sight of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) She's not his mama either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus Gorman, this is my Psychic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nutritionist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cute too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cool. I ain't cute. it ain't cool to be cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS sits down by the oversized chess set. Unthinkingly, h one of the black pieces. immediately three of the white p squares automatically realigning themselves in a new defe gadgetry. Startled, GUS backs away. NEW ANGLE -- As ROSS stares at GUS'S reaction, behind him plunked herself in his chair behind the desk. The right h and she reaches in to take a Kleenex when VERA, seeing he by swiftly and slams the drawer closed with her knee, sma fingers. The later lets out a shriek and pulls her hand, wildly. ROSS turns to see what's the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's drying her nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORELEI smile through her pain, keeps shaking her hand in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Always making yourself beautiful for me, aren't you? (turns back to GUS) So, Gus, can you make Vulcan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: do what I want it to? You didn't answer me, pal. (as GUS hesitates) Did you hear about that prison riot last week? It seems they were complaining about rats in the cells...

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (quickly) Yeah, yeah, I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: First question got to be "Where."

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Not "What." Don't need a genius to figure out "what." Need a  genius to figure out "where." (A bit boastfully to VERA) He says I'm a genius, your don -- (quickly) Brother! Bubba! Your Bubba! (as she calms down) See, if y'all don't want them to trace it back, you got to punch this in from someplace nobody'd ever think off. Some little rinky- dink operation with a little mickey- mouse computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got to be someplace you can sneak into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someplace where nobody knows him so they can't connect him with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Webco has a hundred and twelve subsidiaries and every one of them is tied to our central computer system. How about...hmmmm, someplace small...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON THE WORD "Smallville" painted on a sign. PUL BAC ENTIRE SIGN: "Smallville Groceries." WIDE SHOT -- The main shopping area of Smallville. In B.G out of the grocery store, carrying a bag of picnic suppli CLARK sits in the front seat of her 5-year \-old Chevy. R playing with his very frisky puppy, BUSTER. In F.G. LEFT discharging some PASSENGERS, many carrying suitcases. CLOSER ON THE CAR -- as CLARK sees LANA struggling with t and hefting her bag of supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give your mom a hand.

dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- he flings open the car door and it slams har MAN who just got off the bus. The GUY howls with pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abashed) Oh, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the MAN limps off, muttering, we realize it's GUS GORM old beat-up windbreaker and slacks, but now carrying a Vu GUS, as he walks across some railroad tracks that run thr town, looking around at his surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitching, aloud) Welcome to nowhere, U.S.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In B.G. LANA and CLARK get in the car and drive off. HOLD he sets off down Main Street, passing a Sears type store, window display. A mannequin-like giant Ken doll in a gree leisure suit is grinning down at him. GUS shudders from t HOLD CAMAERA STAIONARY as SEEN FROM BEHIND, shoulders bow Main Street and off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME LONG SHOT -- In a clearing on the edge of acres o and LANA and RICKY and BUSTER the puppy are ensconced bet parked on the side of the road, and a picket fence that m farm. CLOSER -- On their picnic blanket LANA is proudly setting plastic containers of homemade goodies as CLARK sprinkles stalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) Gee, I haven't done this in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people don't think it's healthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly nodding) Well, it's true you have to be careful things don't spoil, especially with mayonnaise  or cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark, I think you worry too much about mayonnaise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about salt. (as he hesitates uncertainly) Oh, go ahead, pour it on, relax. That's what picnics are for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- including RICKY, who is pulling a ball out o BUSTER waits, wagging his tail, beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they have picnics in Metropolis, Mr. Kent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (looking around at  the open fields, clean air, blue sky)         Not quite like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom and I do this all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he goes racing off with BUSTER, OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to CLARK) It's nice for Ricky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARK settles in next to her, beginning to open plastic c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying the proximity) And even nicer when there's a man around, Which isn't all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: that often.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (re the plastic containers) There's a lot of choices here.

dialogues.speaker: LANA
dialogues.text: No, all the good ones are married. That's why Brad thinks he's God's gift to women. This woman anyway. He's single. He won't take no  for an answer, but he's the only one who's asking. And he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (trying to straighten out the conversation) I meant all the choices here. All this -- (lifting lids) -- cole slaw, guacamole -- (more and more impressed as he opens for containers) This is some picnic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICKY RUNS TO HER. LANA is still beaming from CLARK'S pra

dialogues.text: Hey mom, how about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANA finds -- in the middle of this feast -- a lone, wax and hands it to RICKY with a mock sigh. As he takes off a TWO SHOT -- LANA turns back to CLARK. Holding a fork and has just sampled something he's not quite sure about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peanut butter and jelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean Ricky. He's not interested in any of this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this pate is rather...unusual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pate? What pate? (leaning over -- very close to him now -- to peer into the container) I didn't make any -- (horrified pause; then) Oh, no, Clark. That's Buster's dog food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARK looks at the container, looks at his fork, looks at face is just too much for her. She starts to laugh. Then They stop -- and then start again. She collapses against laughter. And even when their mirth subsides, they don't move apart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I haven't laughed like that since -- since -- (she suddenly realizes) I really can't remember when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their proximity suddenly makes them self-conscious. They lighten the moment, a bit awkwardly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...how much longer do you think you'll be in Smallville --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his dialogue overlaps hers, starts a few beats back) You know, I was just thinking, Lana --  (the following line         is in the clear) -- someone like you could do do really well in Metropolis --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both stop, smile a bit shyly at each other. Sound: nearby, the steady, grinding motor of a giant thre fields. EXT. WHEAT FIELDS: LONG SHOT of the enormous thresher cut its great blades and rollers turning. ON THE PICNIC: over the noise, LANA and CLARK are continu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I've got to face it -- I'm not going to find what I want in Smallville anymore, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound: the thresher gets closer and louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I can never get a way from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following her thought about Smallville; nodding understandingly) Old ties are hard to cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I mean, yes they are, but I         was talking about that. (she cocks her head towards the insistent sound) Wheat King. Bet your bottom  dollar that's a Wheat King  thresher. (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) That's the biggest change in Smallville, you know. They've taken over this town. Everybody who isn't actually working for Wheat King -- like I do -- is out there -- (gesturing towards the fields) on a Wheat King thresher. (back to their conversation; she looks up at him eagerly) Do you think I could do it? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubiously) Ride a thresher? Well, I don't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: know. Girls are trying just about  everything now but --

dialogues.speaker: LANA
dialogues.text: No, what you said before, Could I  make it in Metropolis? I've dreamed about it, sure, but I never really thought about it. (uncertainly) What would I do when I got there?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (smiling) Call me.

dialogues.speaker: LANA
dialogues.text: (quietly thrilled) Oh, I wouldn't want to -- I mean, I'd want to, but I wouldn't want  to...be a nuisance to you. ON RICKY -- about twenty feet away, having his own good t with his PUPPY in the tall grass. TWO SHOT -- CLARK and LANA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Hey, you could never be a nuisance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his knee gently. She moves toward him, closer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Clark, may I tell you something? (as he waits, she looks away for a moment) My oil pan is leaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reacts with considerable confusion; it wasn't what he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? (she points under the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV: A small puddle under the CHEVY is getting larger, da but steadily into it as: LANA (o.s.) See? There's something dripping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- As LANA gets up, in B.G. we SEE BUSTER the d wheat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Buster! Darn it... come back, willya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the DOG runs on and RICKY starts to chase him into th and CLARK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog's always doing that. (wryly, pointing to the leaky Chevy) And the car's always doing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANA opens the trunk, takes out a tool kit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. With all the trouble this thing gives me, I started studying up on auto repair.

He sits up, frow towards the wheat fields. EFFECTS: Shimmery light waves coming from his ear denote action.  What he (and we) now HEARS: the plaintive insistent whini fields. Troubled, he turns in that direction, scanning th POV: SPECIAL EFFECTS: X-Ray Vision sees through the thick searching till it finds the PUPPY sitting, whimpering, be unconscious, completely hidden among rows of tall grain. chasing BUSTER, he has tripped and fallen, hitting his he jutting out of the earth beside him. There is a cut on th he doesn't move. Sound: suddenly the grinding, thrashing noise of the gian seems very close. dialogues.text: LOW ANGLE -- RICKY in F.G., the big thresher coming fast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLARK glances over at LANA, but she, of course, has heard underneath the car and goes on tinkering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I'll see if I can help Ricky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and moves casually but very quickly towards th that LANA is safely out of sight doing her work, he darts EFFECTS: As he runs behind the fence, CLARK KENT turns in of the picket railings is like a strobe or time-lapse, i. each rail more and more of the SUPERMAN FIGURE begins to FIGURE. By the time he has reached the end of the fence.. zooms into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SUPERMAN, looking down. HIS POV: the big thresher is getting closer, closer to th FULL SHOT -- SUPERMAN swoops down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. LOW ANGLE -- the thresher comes closer. The noise is deafening. 2. ON THE FRONT OF THE THRESHER -- we can clearly see how formidable the rolling blades are. They would chew the CHILD up in seconds. 3. Accelerating, SUPERMAN dives down, lands in front of the thresher and... 4. Reaches out with both hands and just grabs the churning blades, stopping it abruptly. 5. ON THE THRESHER DRIVER in his cab, startled to find himself coming to a sudden, jolting stop. 6. SUPERMAN scoops up the unconscious RICKY in his arms, flies up into the air with him. 7. RICKY comes to in mid-air, opens his eyes and is surprised to say the least. RICKY Superman??? SUPERMAN That's what they call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8. The thresher DRIVER, in his cab, mops his brow at the near miss. 9. SUPERMAN and RICKY coming towards the  parked car. ON THE CAR -- LANA still underneath. RICKY (o.s.) Mom!  Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANA slides out from under, and is astonished at what she landing with her SON in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ricky?  Where...what...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd wash that out with some iodine... Okay, Mercurochrome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank ...you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICKY gazes at him in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm Lana Lang. This is  Ricky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've already met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is... (she looks around ...Clark. (to SUPERMAN) My friend is around here somewhere, I'll just look for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm in a real hurry. See you around, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a smile and a wave, SUPERMAN takes off. Whoosh. And

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were flying!! Mom! In the sky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying  to make  What were you doing anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking for... Buster!  Buster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound: Distant sound of yelping dog. ON THE WHEAT FIELD -- backing out, ass-first and on his h open-ended length of big irrigation pipe comes a dishevel the PUPPY in his arms. He stands up with difficulty and r the air for them to see in B.G.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- as LANA and RICKY run to CLARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kent! Superman was here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking incredulous) What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He really was!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: "At a special session of the  General Assembly, 178 countries voted to censure Superman. With  only Columbia abstaining."

dialogues.text: That fella's becoming a public menace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bending, pulling) And he use to be such a  sweetie pie! What's wrong with him the last two weeks?

dialogues.text: LORELEI, smiling gamely, immediately starts doing push-up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) That's what I like to see. My two best gals pulling together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE -- revealing GUS GORMAN sitting in a corner of sketching something on the back of an envelope, which he as he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sure wasn't actin' bad and nasty that day in Smallville. Man, he was so full of niceness I was startin' to feel funny about layin' that chunk of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) KRYPTONITE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS, with an expression of "Eureka!" hops off the runnin momentum, however, keeps him running in place. And... TWO SHOT, FULL LENGTH -- without even thinking about it, starts running in place beside him, as they talk, to "kee polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see? Okay, so you didn't kill him. Nobody's perfect. But that stuff we ran up in the lab wasn't a complete failure after all. (explaining) Right after Gus gave it to him, Superman started to turn into a selfish, ornery, malicious, conniving...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (summing it up) A normal person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now that Superman's out of the Nice Guy business...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can get to work on that oil!

dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT (STOCK FOOTAGE): A great stadium with b Olympic Games.

ON THE TOWER AT THE FAR END OF THE STADIUM, with the long leading up to the as-yet-unlit Olympic Flame. We recogniz often-seen ceremony. And now, the supreme moment as the last runner...the one given the great honor of lighting the Olympic Flame...runs the last leg of a marathon that began 7 days ago as this torch has been passed from athlete to  athlete for 970 miles across the  country.

And the RUNNER, terribly confused and upset, has to turn stairs, still carrying the Torch, to go get it re-lit som

dialogues.text: LORELEI is all alone in the office, seated at a table, de book. CLOSER ON HER: The book she's reading with such interest Critique of Pure Reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aloud, puzzled) How can he say that pure categories have no objective  meaning in transcendental  logic? What about synthetic unity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, as she hears the door opening, she hides her bo Gossip magazine and immediately assumes her persona of em WIDE SHOT -- as ROSS, VERA, and GUS enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, honey, am I in your way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in fine fettle) No, stick around, you might learn something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSS presses a button. Suddenly the walls of the office f enormous mural-sized illuminated maps with electronic bli in other words, rapidly transformed into a "War Room" a l CAMERA ON A WALL-SIZED MAP OF THE WORLD, showing all the Illuminated green miniature images of oil tankers are sca bodies of water. PULL BACK TO REVEAL ROSS, a pointer in one hand, a remote other, as he points to the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every oil tanker and super- tanker and super-duper-tanker in the ocean is controlled.  totally, by computers. Computers to tell them where to go, how  much oil to take on, where to deliver it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't got captains?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but they don't really need them. it's just a throw- back to some sentimental sea- faring baloney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will command the tankers to sail toward a 50-mile area in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do nothing. Just sit there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how's all the people gonna get their oil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You catch on fast, old buddy. (to VERA) Tell him about the pumps. I know how you love the part about the pumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERA takes the remote control clicker from ROSS, clicks i ON THE MAP -- the map of the world's oceans disappears an glowing, illuminated map of the United States. Little min shown clustered in all the oil-producing areas of the cou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every pump in America is run...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, by computers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop interrupting ?! (calming herself) You will command the pumps to stop pumping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gleeful) And then shut down the pipe lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pumps stop pumping oil. Pipe lines stop pipin' oil. Tankers stop deliverin' oil. Man, this is high stakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flattered) Thanks, kiddo. now, listen,  this part's important. I want you to program one special  command into all these systems. Tell them these orders are irreversible, so it'll be impossible for anybody to  switch them back. Can you do that, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON GUS -- a pause. he looks upset about something, buildi it. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit, you're getting' what you want all the time. it ain't right that I don't get somethin'! I never get somethin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it, I knew it, go be nice to people and they think they can ask for the moon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (het up) The moon! Listen, man, when I was a little bitty kid all my  friends got them electric trains  for Christmas. My mama didn't have barely enough to pay the electric bill, let alone buy me no train set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sounds like it's going to  be sad. I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now...when do I get a taste?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (naked threat)                 I should think a taste of freedom is enough, don't you? Or would you prefer jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defiantly) Don't lay that jail number on me no more. You need me out here doin' stuff for you more'n sitten' in no jail doin' nothin' for nobody. (pointedly) 'Sides, I be known' some heavy stuff about you now. You don't want em spillin' the coffee beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before ROSS can even ask her, LORELEI discretely leaves t are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this blackmail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be getting' racist with me, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this whitemail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair's fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON GUS -- He starts emptying the contents of his pockets all matchbooks, paper napkins, backs of envelopes, scrap plans and numbers are scrawled on all of them. ON ROSS -- looking at this pile of crumpled effluvia. he up his waste basket, holds it up to GUS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waste-basket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are plans. (as ROSS eyes them skeptically) Blueprints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've already got some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like this one you ain't. Nobody in the world got one like this 'cause it don't exist yet. We got to build it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) You designed it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) I invented it, man. In my head. It's a stone killer-diller get-down get-it-on and twice-on-Sunday

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: super mutha computer.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (intrigued) What will it do?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Everything.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What will it get me?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (a big genial smile) Tell me more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All alone in the computer room, GUS sits at his console a coordinates.

As it moves into place: Sound: Someone applauds and utters a small female "yay!" WIDE SHOT -- LORELEI is applauding. ROSS is standing besi the glowing convoy. VERA does not look so happy.

dialogues.text: That's it! The last tanker! They're all mine now! All...

dialogues.text: (riled) That's the middle of the Atlantic Ocean! And I am not taking my ship out there to just sit, no matter what no damn machine says. We're supposed to go to Metropolis and we're going to Metropolis!
